hints_html: Work with the MacLaurin series for \(\sin x\) first, then manipulate it.
hints_latex: Work with the MacLaurin series for $\sin x$ first, then manipulate it.
hints_raw: Work with the MacLaurin series for <math> \sin x </math> first, then manipulate it.
question: 2 (c)
sols_html:
Recall the MacLaurin series for sin(x) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \sin(x) = x - \frac{x^3}{3!} + \ldots\end{aligned}\]

so

\[\begin{aligned} x^2\sin(x^3) &= x^2\left(x^3 - \frac{x^9}{3!} + \ldots\right) \\ &= x^5 - \frac{x^{11}}{3!} + \ldots\end{aligned}\]

so

\[\begin{aligned} a = 1, b = -\frac{1}{6}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Recall the MacLaurin series for sin(''x'') is given by
:<math> \sin(x) = x - \frac{x^3}{3!} + \ldots </math>
so
:<math> \begin{align} 
x^2\sin(x^3) & = x^2\left(x^3 - \frac{x^9}{3!} + \ldots\right) \\
& = x^5 - \frac{x^{11}}{3!} + \ldots
\end{align} </math>
so
:<math> a = 1, b = -\frac{1}{6} </math>
statement_html:
Short-Answer Questions. Question 1-3 are short-answer questions. Put your answer in the box provided. Simplify your answer as much as possible. Full Marks will be awarded for a correct answer placed in the box. Show your work, for part marks.

The first two terms in the Maclaurin series for \(x^2\sin(x^3)\) are \(ax^5+bx^{11}\), where a and b are constants. Find the values of a and b.
